Title:
An overview of 23 years of molecular markers studies in
Phallales (Basidiomycota) with notes on systematics and geographic
distribution
Keywords:
Gasteroid fungus, GenBank, phylogenetic analyses,
stinkhorns, UNITE.
Abstract:
The order Phallales (Basidiomycota) is represented by
gasteroid fungi with expanded and sequestrate basidiomata known as
stinkhorns and false truffles. The use of molecular DNA in taxonomy has
brought a new tool to obtain answers to some phylogenetic hypotheses. In
phalloid, the first DNA sequence was published in 1997, and after that
some studies aimed to resolve conflicts and propose new species based on
DNA markers phylogeny. Even though molecular DNA data has been included
in studies since 1997, the number of families in the order still
generates controversies among researchers. Thus, this work aims to
provide an overview of Phallales diversity represented by selected DNA
markers available in public databases. We retrieved identified Phallales
sequences from DNA databases (GenBank and UNITE) of seven markers (ITS,
nuc-LSU, nuc-SSU, mt-SSU, ATP6, RPB2, and TEF1-Î±). To compound our final
dataset all ITS sequences retrieved have gone through BLASTn searches to
identify ITS sequences not classified as Phallales. Phylogenetic
analyses based on Bayesian and Maximum Likelihood approaches using
single and combinate markers were conducted. Thereby all ITS sequences
were clustered with a cutoff of 98% in order to recognize the number of
species hypothesis. The geographic origin of sequences was retrieved. We
obtained a total of 1,149 sequences representing 664 individuals. The
total of 43 individuals were without genus identification, in which were
placed in five distinctive families. We recognize seven families and 22
genera in Phallales, confirming the synonymies Phallus (=Dictyophora)
and Mutinus (=Jansia). Many inconsistencies in species identification
were discussed and the genera positions in each family were analyzed.
Based on 98.0% sequence similarity threshold, the clustering revealed
118 species hypotheses in Phallales; approximately 20% of the described
species of Phallales have DNA sequence located in DNA databases.
Information related to country of origin included in DNA databases
represent 462 individuals distributed in 46 countries. Great progress in
the molecular analyses of phalloids has already been made over these
years, but it is still necessary to solve some taxonomy inconsistencies
and generate new data by expanding the knowledge of the group.
